p: The structure of Singapore is a matrix of highly populated areas with parks and bosquets, resulting in a vegetation cover of 44% [ 31]. Forested areas such as parks are frequented weekly by at least 35% of the population [ 32] and possess all social and environmental characteristics identified in foci of infection [ 33], i.e. routine attendance, artificial or natural containers, open spaces for daily activities, and the lack of air-conditioning. To determine the potential risk of infection in these sites, we combine country-wide entomological surveys and vector competence studies to determine the distribution and prevalence of competent vectors.
